captions.text: We've already done direct free kicks, now we're going to do some indirect ones, a bit more organized and as a team.
Two people on the ball, to create a disguise and confusion for the keeper. Then we've got a player here who looks distracted.
You'll look as if you your going to strike it, but what you do is you play it in there for Bilal's run.
We've got a left footer and a right footer over the ball. You can get movement, and people in the goalkeeper's eye-line, which makes it very difficult.
Yes! Good strike. Same sort of position, but now he's going to be the decoy. It looks as if you were going to pass it to Webby,
and what you do is a back-heal, and it goes into Eric.
So we can to keep the same type of set up, but then we use variations that give you that element of surprise.
Which is obviously the most important thing in any set piece.
A variation or progression within this, is to chip it over the wall. Now you spin and it's important that you try to connect with the ball
through a volley if you can. People have to move at the right time. If they go too early, you can still see the ball.
Now we are going to try to do a clever volley. Great effort!
The wall will be set, and its just about shifting the ball to take the wall out of it.
We've got two men on the ball which means the keeper can't see it until late.
The weight of your pass has to be right because remember that there will be a charger.
Well hitting the post or the bar always gives your team-mates a chance as well.
Has to be sharp. Yes! Well done.
Having the same set up provokes them to think "we've seen this one, that's the one they did in the first half".
But hold on a minute, that's a progression. We're going to finish off with an attacking wide free-kick.
That ball has to be chipped in there. And then he can either strike it or play it into there, okay?
For the next one, your target is aiming for this back post. How many goals do we see where these guys come and get into the eye-line,
everyone misses it and the keeper cannot react until its beaten everybody and the ball sweeps into the far post.
That is where you're looking to hit, okay? If you all start thrusting it, its horrible to mark. It's about desire and delivery.
Brilliant, there we go. And that has got to be a goal. That is the perfect delivery.
Keeper's in no man's land, defender will be facing his own goal, in the widths of their own goal, they hate it!
You give them the tools, and they have to make the decisions as players.
